question: What was the outcome of the plaintiffs' motion for class certification in the case against Facebook, Inc. in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California?
ground_truth: On March 29, 2022, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification.
contexts:

Facebook, Inc.) and seek unspecified damages and injunctive relief. In a series of rulings in 2019, 2021, and 2022, the court dismissed certain of the plaintiffs' claims, but permitted their fraud and unfair competition claims to proceed. On March 29, 2022, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification. On June 21, 2022, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted our petition for permission to appeal the district court's class certification order, and the court heard argument on September 12, 2023. The case is stayed in the district court pending appeal.

Beginning on July 7, 2023, multiple putative class actions were filed against us in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California (Kadrey, et al. v. Meta Platforms, Inc. et al.), which was subsequently transferred to the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California) alleging that we used various copyrighted books and materials to train our artificial intelligence models, and seeking unspecified damages and injunctive relief.

In addition, we are subject to litigation and other proceedings involving law enforcement and other regulatory agencies, including in particular in Brazil, Russia, and other countries in Europe, in order to ascertain the precise scope of our legal obligations to comply with the requests of those agencies, including our obligation to disclose user information in particular circumstances. A number of such instances have resulted in the assessment of fines and penalties against us. We believe we have multiple legal grounds to satisfy these requests or prevail against associated fines and penalties, and we intend to vigorously defend such fines and penalties.

Indemnifications

In the normal course of business, to facilitate transactions of services and products, we have agreed to indemnify certain parties with respect to certain matters. We have agreed to hold certain parties harmless against losses arising from a breach of representations or covenants, or out of intellectual property infringement or other claims made by third parties. These agreements may limit the time within which an indemnification claim can be made and the amount of the claim. In addition, we have entered into indemnification agreements with our officers, directors, and certain employees, and our certificate of incorporation and bylaws contain similar indemnification obligations.

It is not possible to determine the maximum potential amount under these indemnification agreements due to the limited history of prior indemnification claims and the unique facts and circumstances involved in each particular agreement. Historically, payments made by us under these agreements have not had a material impact on our consolidated financial statements. In our opinion, as of December 31, 2023, there was not a reasonable possibility we had incurred a material loss with respect to indemnification of such parties. We have not recorded any liability for costs related to indemnification through December 31, 2023.

response: In the case against Facebook, Inc. in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, the plaintiffs' motion for class certification was granted on March 29, 2022. This allowed the plaintiffs to proceed as a class in their legal action against Facebook, Inc. However, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit later granted a petition for permission to appeal the certification order on June 21, 2022, and a hearing was held on September 12, 2023. question: What is the definition of Monthly Active People (MAP) and how is it calculated?
ground_truth: Monthly Active People (MAP) is defined as a registered and logged-in user of one or more Family products who visited at least one of these Family products through a mobile device application or using a web or mobile browser in the last 30 days as of the date of measurement. The calculation of MAP relies upon complex techniques, algorithms, and machine learning models that seek to estimate the underlying number of unique people using one or more of these products, including by matching user accounts within an individual product and across multiple products when they are believed to be attributable to a single person, and counting such group of accounts as one person.
contexts:
these Family products through a mobile device application or using a web or mobile browser on a given day. We do not require people to use a common identifier or link their accounts to use multiple products in our Family, and therefore must seek to attribute multiple user accounts within and across products to individual people. Our calculations of DAP rely upon complex techniques, algorithms, and machine learning models that seek to estimate the underlying number of unique people using one or more of these products, including by matching user accounts within an individual product and across multiple products when we believe they are attributable to a single person, and counting such group of accounts as one person. As these techniques and models require significant judgment, are developed based on internal reviews of limited samples of user accounts, and are calibrated against user survey data, there is necessarily some margin of error in our estimates. We view DAP, and DAP as a percentage of MAP, as measures of engagement across our products. For additional information, see the section entitled "Limitations of Key Metrics and Other Data" in this Annual Report on Form 10-K.

DAP/MAP: 79% 79% 79% 78% 79% 79% 79% 79% 79%

Note: We report the numbers of DAP and MAP as specific amounts, but these numbers are estimates of the numbers of unique people using our products and are subject to statistical variances and errors. While we expect the error margin for these estimates to vary from period to period, we estimate that such margin generally will be approximately 3% of our worldwide MAP. At our scale, it is very difficult to attribute multiple user accounts within and across products to individual people, and it is possible that the actual numbers of unique people using our products may vary significantly from our estimates, potentially beyond our estimated error margins. For additional information, see the section entitled "Limitations of Key Metrics and Other Data" in this Annual Report on Form 10-K. In the third quarter of 2022, we updated our Family metrics calculations to maintain calibration of our models against recent user survey data, and we estimate such update contributed an aggregate of approximately 30 million DAP to our reported worldwide DAP in September 2022.

Worldwide DAP increased 5% to 2.96 billion on average during December 2022 from 2.82 billion during December 2021.

response:
**Monthly Active People (MAP)** is defined as a registered and logged-in user of one or more Family products who has visited at least one of these products through a mobile device application or using a web or mobile browser in the last 30 days as of the date of measurement. 

### Calculation of MAP

The calculation of MAP involves several key steps:

1. **User Identification**: MAP counts users who are registered and have logged into the Family of products. This includes users across various platforms and devices.

2. **Activity Measurement**: A user is considered "active" if they have accessed any of the Family products at least once during the 30-day measurement period. This can be through mobile applications or web browsers.

3. **Account Matching**: The calculation employs complex techniques, algorithms, and machine learning models to match user accounts within individual products and across multiple products. This is important because users may have multiple accounts or use different products within the Family.

4. **Estimation Techniques**: The methodology seeks to estimate the underlying number of unique individuals using the products. This involves treating a group of accounts that are believed to belong to a single individual as one person.

5. **Margin of Error**: Due to the complexities involved in estimating unique users, there is a margin of error in the MAP estimates, typically around 3% of the total count.

Overall, MAP serves as a key metric for understanding the size of the active user community for the Family of products and provides insights into user engagement and growth trends.

question: What challenges are associated with managing the scale and complexity of a large business operation?
ground_truth: The challenges associated with managing the scale and complexity of a large business operation include managing multiple relationships with users, marketers, developers, and other third parties, maintaining information technology systems and internal controls and procedures that support the scale and complexity of the business, and effectively training and managing personnel. Additionally, there are challenges related to productivity and collaboration due to remote work, risks associated with organizational changes such as restructurings and layoffs, and difficulties in maintaining corporate culture and quickly developing and launching new products.
contexts:
factors that require us to apply different methodologies for such adjustments. We generally do not intend to update previously disclosed Family metrics for any such inaccuracies or adjustments that are within the error margins disclosed below.

In addition, our Family metrics estimates will differ from estimates published by third parties due to differences in methodology or other factors such as data limitations or other challenges in measuring large online and mobile populations. For example, our methodologies include measurements of our user base that have in some instances exceeded estimates of addressable online and mobile populations that are based on data published by third parties.

Many people in our community have user accounts on more than one of our products, and some people have multiple user accounts within an individual product. Accordingly, for our Family metrics, we do not seek to count the total number of user accounts across our products because we believe that would not reflect the actual size of our community. Rather, our Family metrics represent our estimates of the number of unique people using at least one of Facebook, Instagram, Messenger, and WhatsApp. We do not require people to use a common identifier or link their accounts to use multiple products in our Family, and therefore must seek to attribute multiple user accounts within and across products to individual people. To calculate these metrics, we rely upon complex techniques, algorithms and machine learning models that seek to count the individual people behind user accounts, including by matching multiple user accounts within an individual product and across multiple products when we believe they are attributable to a single person, and counting such group of accounts as one person. These techniques and models require significant judgment, are subject to data and other limitations discussed below, and inherently are subject to statistical variances and uncertainties. We estimate the potential error in our Family metrics primarily based on user survey data as described further below, which itself is subject to error as well. While we expect the error margin for our Family metrics to vary from period to period, we estimate that such margin generally will be approximately 3% of our worldwide DAP. At our scale, it is very difficult to attribute multiple user accounts within and across products to individual people, and it is possible that the actual numbers of unique people using our products may vary significantly from our estimates, potentially beyond our estimated error margins. As a result, it is also possible that our Family metrics may indicate changes or trends in user numbers that do not match actual changes or trends.

68

Table of Contents

To calculate our estimates of DAP, we currently use a series of machine learning models that are developed based on internal reviews of limited samples of user accounts and calibrated against user survey data. We apply significant judgment in designing these models and calculating these estimates. For example, to match user accounts within individual products and across multiple products, we use data signals such as similar device information, IP addresses, and user names. We also calibrate our models against data from periodic user surveys of varying sizes and frequency across our products, which survey questions are based on monthly usage, and which are inherently subject to error. The timing and results of such user surveys have in the past contributed, and may in the future contribute, to changes in our reported Family metrics from period to period. In addition, our data limitations may affect our understanding of certain details of our business and increase the risk of error for our Family metrics estimates. Our techniques and models rely on a variety of data signals from different products, and we rely on more limited data signals for some products compared to others. For example, as a result of limited visibility into encrypted products, we have fewer data signals from WhatsApp user accounts and primarily rely on phone numbers and device information to match WhatsApp user accounts with accounts on our other products. Any loss of access to data signals we use in our process for calculating Family metrics, whether as a result of our own product decisions, actions by third-party browser or mobile platforms, regulatory or legislative requirements, or other factors, also may impact the stability or accuracy of our reported Family metrics, as well as our ability to report these metrics at all. Our estimates of Family metrics also may change as our methodologies evolve, including through the application of new data signals or technologies, product changes, or other improvements in our user surveys, algorithms, or machine learning that may improve our ability to match accounts within and across our products or otherwise evaluate the broad population of our users. In addition, such evolution may allow us to identify previously undetected violating accounts (as defined below).

We regularly evaluate our Family metrics to estimate the percentage of our DAP consisting solely of "violating" accounts. We define "violating" accounts as accounts which we believe are intended to be used for purposes that violate our terms of service, including bots and spam. In the first quarter of 2024, we estimated that less than 3% of our worldwide DAP consisted solely of violating accounts. Such estimation is based on an internal review of a limited sample of accounts, and we apply significant judgment in making this determination. For example, we look for account information and behaviors associated with Facebook and Instagram accounts that appear

to be inauthentic to the reviewers, but we have limited visibility into WhatsApp user activity due to encryption. In addition, if we believe an individual person has one or more violating accounts, we do not include such person in our violating accounts estimation as long as we believe they have one account that does not constitute a violating account. From time to time, we disable certain user accounts, make product changes, or take other actions to reduce the number of violating accounts among our users, which may also reduce our DAP estimates in a particular period. We intend to disclose our estimates of the percentage of our DAP consisting solely of violating accounts on an annual basis in our Annual Report on Form 10-K. Violating accounts are very difficult to measure at our scale, and it is possible that the actual number of violating accounts may vary significantly from our estimates.

Other data limitations also may affect our understanding of certain details of our business. For example, while user-provided data indicates a decline in usage among younger users, this age data may be unreliable because a disproportionate number of our younger users register with an inaccurate age. Accordingly, our understanding of usage by age group may not be complete.

Our estimates for revenue by user location, as well as year-over-year percentage changes in ad impressions delivered and the average price per ad by user location, are also affected by data limitations and other challenges in measuring user geography. Our data regarding the geographic location of our users is estimated based on a number of factors, such as the user's IP address and self-disclosed location. These factors may not always accurately reflect the user's actual location. For example, a user may appear to be accessing our products from the location of the proxy server that the user connects to rather than from the user's actual location. The methodologies used to measure our metrics are also susceptible to algorithm or other technical errors.

In addition, from time to time we provide, or rely on, certain other metrics and estimates, including those relating to the reach and effectiveness of our ads. Many of our metrics involve the use of estimations and judgments, and our metrics and estimates are subject to software bugs, inconsistencies in our systems, and human error. Such metrics and estimates also change from time to time due to improvements or changes in our terminology or methodology, including as a result of loss of access to data signals we use in calculating such metrics and estimates. We have been, and may in the future be, subject to litigation as well as marketer, regulatory, and other inquiries regarding the accuracy of such metrics and estimates. Where marketers, developers, or investors do not perceive our metrics or estimates to be accurate, or where we discover material inaccuracies in our metrics or estimates, we may be subject to liability, our reputation may be harmed, and marketers and developers may be less willing to allocate their budgets or resources to our products that deliver ad impressions, which could negatively affect our business and financial results.

69

Table of Contents

We cannot assure you that we will effectively manage our scale.

Our employee headcount and the scale and complexity of our business have increased significantly over time. The scale of our business and breadth of our products create significant challenges for our management, operational, and financial resources, including managing multiple relationships with users, marketers, developers, and other third parties, and maintaining information technology systems and internal controls and procedures that support the scale and complexity of our business. In addition, some members of our management do not have significant experience managing a large global business operation, so our management may not be able to manage our scale effectively. To effectively manage our scale, we must maintain, and continue to adapt, our operational, financial, and management processes and systems, manage our headcount and facilities, and effectively train and manage our personnel. Many of our personnel work remotely, which may lead to challenges in productivity and collaboration. In addition, from time to time, we implement organizational changes to pursue greater efficiency and realign our business and strategic priorities. For example, in 2022 and 2023, we announced several initiatives, including restructurings, employee layoffs, and measures to scale down our office facilities, but we cannot guarantee that they will achieve our intended results. These efforts also subject us to risks such as greater than anticipated costs, adverse effects on employee retention, and increased difficulty managing the scale and complexity of our business. For example, we could face delays or challenges with product development, other business and strategic initiatives, or legal and regulatory compliance, as well as other disruptions to our operations. As our organization continues to evolve, and we are required to implement and adapt complex organizational management structures, we may find it difficult to maintain the benefits of our corporate culture, including our ability to quickly develop and launch new and innovative products. Any of these developments could negatively affect our business, reputation, or financial results.

We have significant international operations, which subject us to increased business, economic, and legal risks that could affect our financial results.

We have significant international operations
response:
Managing the scale and complexity of a large business operation presents several challenges, including:

### 1. **Operational Complexity**
- **Coordination of Multiple Functions**: Large organizations often have various departments and functions (e.g., marketing, finance, production, and logistics) that must be coordinated effectively. Ensuring alignment and communication among these functions can be challenging.
- **Process Standardization**: Implementing standardized processes across different locations or departments can be difficult, leading to inconsistencies and inefficiencies.

### 2. **Resource Management**
- **Human Resources**: Managing a large workforce involves challenges related to recruitment, training, retention, and motivation. Ensuring that employees are aligned with the company's goals and culture can be particularly difficult in a large organization.
- **Financial Resources**: Large operations require substantial financial resources for investment in infrastructure, technology, and personnel. Managing cash flow and investment priorities can be complex.

### 3. **Technological Integration**
- **Information Technology Systems**: Maintaining and integrating various information technology systems that support the scale and complexity of operations is crucial. Ensuring that these systems can handle large volumes of data and transactions without downtime is a significant challenge.
- **Cybersecurity Risks**: As organizations grow, they become more vulnerable to cyber threats. Protecting sensitive data and ensuring compliance with regulations is increasingly complex in a large operation.

### 4. **Market Dynamics**
- **Competitive Pressure**: Large organizations often face intense competition from both established players and new entrants. Adapting to market changes and customer preferences while maintaining operational efficiency can be challenging.
- **Global Operations**: For businesses operating internationally, navigating different regulatory environments, cultural differences, and economic conditions adds layers of complexity to management.

### 5. **Change Management**
- **Resistance to Change**: Implementing changes in processes, technology, or organizational structure can meet resistance from employees accustomed to existing ways of working. Managing this change effectively is crucial for success.
- **Agility and Adaptability**: Large organizations may struggle to respond quickly to market changes or emerging opportunities due to their size and established processes. Maintaining agility while scaling operations is a significant challenge.

### 6. **Regulatory Compliance**
- **Complex Regulatory Environment**: Large businesses often operate in multiple jurisdictions with varying regulations. Ensuring compliance with local, national, and international laws can be resource-intensive and complex.
- **Risk Management**: Identifying, assessing, and mitigating risks associated with large-scale operations is critical. This includes financial, operational, reputational, and compliance risks.

### 7. **Cultural Integration**
- **Diverse Workforce**: Managing a diverse workforce with varying backgrounds, experiences, and expectations can create challenges in fostering a cohesive organizational culture.
- **Alignment of Values**: Ensuring that all employees are aligned with the company’s mission and values can be more challenging in large organizations, where subcultures may develop.

### 8. **Performance Measurement**
- **Data Management**: Collecting and analyzing data across a large organization to measure performance can be complex. Ensuring that key performance indicators (KPIs) are relevant and effectively communicated is essential.
- **Accountability and Governance**: Establishing clear accountability and governance structures to oversee operations and ensure compliance with policies and procedures is crucial for managing complexity.

### Summary

In summary, managing the scale and complexity of a large business operation involves challenges related to operational coordination, resource management, technological integration, market dynamics, change management, regulatory compliance, cultural integration, and performance measurement. Addressing these challenges requires effective leadership, strategic planning, and robust systems to ensure that the organization can operate efficiently and adapt to changing conditions.

question: What are the potential impacts of technical infrastructure challenges on the business's reputation and financial performance?
ground_truth: Technical infrastructure challenges can damage the business's reputation, result in a potential loss of users and engagement, and adversely affect financial results. If products or services are unavailable or do not perform as expected, users may not use them as often or at all, and the ability to serve ads may be disrupted.
contexts:
other catastrophic events and crises. For example, the COVID-19 pandemic previously significantly impacted our business and results of operations. In particular, the pandemic resulted in authorities implementing numerous preventative measures from time to time to contain or mitigate the outbreak of the virus, such as travel bans and restrictions, limitations on business activity, quarantines, and shelter-in-place orders, which caused business slowdowns or shutdowns in certain affected countries and regions. These developments led to volatility in the demand for and pricing of our advertising services at various points throughout the pandemic, and we may experience similar effects in the future as a result of the pandemic or other catastrophic events. Such events also expose our business, operations, and workforce to a variety of other risks, including: volatility in the size of our user base and user engagement; delays in product development or releases, or reductions in manufacturing production and sales of consumer hardware, as a result of inventory shortages, supply chain or labor shortages; significant volatility and disruption of global financial markets, which could cause fluctuations in currency exchange rates or negatively impact our ability to access capital in the future; illnesses to key employees, or a significant portion of our workforce, which may result in inefficiencies, delays, and disruptions in our business; and increased volatility and uncertainty in the financial projections we use as the basis for estimates used in our financial statements. Any of these developments may adversely affect our business, harm our reputation, or result in legal or regulatory actions against us.

We incur significant expenses in operating our business, and some of our investments, particularly our investments in Reality Labs as well as our artificial intelligence initiatives, have the effect of reducing our operating margin and profitability. If our investments are not successful longer-term, our business and financial performance will be harmed.

We incur significant expenses in operating our business, and we expect our expenses to continue to increase in the future as we broaden our user base, as users increase the amount and types of content they consume and the data they share with us, for example with respect to video, as we develop and implement new products, as we market new and existing products and promote our brands, as we continue to expand our technical infrastructure, as we continue to invest in new and unproven technologies, including AI and machine learning, and as we continue our efforts to focus on privacy, safety, security, and content and advertising review and enforcement. We have previously undertaken cost reduction measures in light of a more challenging operating environment, which may adversely affect these or other business initiatives, and some of these measures have involved, and may in the future involve, up-front charges and outlays of cash to reduce certain longer-term expenses. In addition, from time to time we are subject to settlements, judgments, fines, or other monetary penalties in connection with legal and regulatory developments that may be material to our business. We are also continuing to increase our investments in new platforms and technologies, including as part of our efforts related to building the metaverse. Some of these investments, particularly our significant investments in Reality Labs, have generated only limited revenue and reduced our operating margin and profitability, and we expect the adverse financial impact of such investments to continue for the foreseeable future. For example, our investments in Reality Labs reduced our 2023 overall operating profit by approximately $16.12 billion, and we expect our Reality Labs investments and operating losses to increase meaningfully in 2024. If our investments are not successful longer-term, our business and financial performance will be harmed.

Our business is dependent on our ability to maintain and scale our technical infrastructure, and any significant disruption in our products and services could damage our reputation, result in a potential loss of users and engagement, and adversely affect our financial results.

Our reputation and ability to attract, retain, and serve our users is dependent upon the reliable performance of our products and services and our underlying technical infrastructure. We have experienced, and may in the future experience, interruptions in the availability or performance of our products and services from time to time. Our systems may not be adequately designed or may not operate with the reliability and redundancy necessary to avoid performance delays or outages that could be harmful to our business. If our products or services are unavailable when users attempt to access them, or if they do not load as quickly as expected, users may not use our products or services as often in the future, or at all, and our ability to serve ads may be disrupted, any of which could adversely affect our business and financial performance. We have experienced such issues to varying degrees from time to time. In addition, as the amount and types of information shared on our products continue to grow and evolve, as the usage patterns of our global community continue to evolve, and as our internal operational demands continue to grow, especially with the deployment of AI technologies, we will need an increasing amount of technical infrastructure, including network capacity, computing power, and related energy requirements, to continue to satisfy our needs. response:
Technical infrastructure challenges can have significant impacts on a business's reputation and financial performance. Here are some potential effects:

### 1. **Reputation Damage**
- **Service Interruptions**: Frequent outages or disruptions in service can lead to customer dissatisfaction. If users experience unreliable access to products or services, it can erode trust and loyalty, damaging the brand's reputation.
- **Negative Publicity**: Technical failures often attract media attention, leading to negative coverage that can harm public perception. A tarnished reputation can take a long time to rebuild, affecting customer acquisition and retention.
- **Customer Complaints and Feedback**: Increased customer complaints due to technical issues can create a perception of incompetence. Social media and online reviews can amplify negative experiences, further damaging the brand image.

### 2. **Customer Retention and Engagement**
- **Loss of Users**: If technical challenges persist, customers may seek alternatives, resulting in a loss of users and reduced engagement. This attrition can have long-term implications for customer loyalty and brand equity.
- **Decreased User Experience**: Technical issues can lead to a subpar user experience, which may deter current and potential users from engaging with the business. A poor user experience can negatively impact conversion rates and overall satisfaction.

### 3. **Financial Performance**
- **Revenue Loss**: Service disruptions can directly affect revenue, especially for businesses reliant on subscriptions or transaction-based models. A decline in active users can lead to decreased sales and profitability.
- **Increased Operating Costs**: Addressing technical infrastructure challenges often requires significant investments in repairs, upgrades, or replacements. This can lead to increased operational costs, affecting overall financial performance.
- **Regulatory Fines and Legal Costs**: If technical failures lead to breaches of data security or compliance issues, businesses may face regulatory fines or legal costs. These financial penalties can further strain resources and impact profitability.

### 4. **Market Position**
- **Competitive Disadvantage**: Companies facing persistent technical infrastructure challenges may fall behind competitors who offer more reliable services. This can result in a loss of market share and hinder growth opportunities.
- **Investor Confidence**: Technical difficulties and their impact on reputation and performance may lead to decreased investor confidence. This can affect stock prices and the ability to raise capital for future investments.

### 5. **Long-term Strategic Implications**
- **Impact on Innovation**: Resources diverted to address technical challenges may limit the ability to invest in innovation or new product development. This can hinder the business's ability to adapt to market changes or capitalize on new opportunities.
- **Cultural and Employee Morale**: Ongoing technical issues can affect employee morale and productivity. If employees are frustrated by infrastructure problems, it can lead to decreased job satisfaction and higher turnover rates, impacting overall organizational effectiveness.

### Summary

In summary, technical infrastructure challenges can lead to significant reputational damage, loss of customer trust, decreased financial performance, and a competitive disadvantage. Addressing these challenges proactively is crucial for maintaining a positive brand image, ensuring customer satisfaction, and securing long-term business success. Investing in robust technical infrastructure and maintaining effective communication with stakeholders can help mitigate these risks.

question: What are the reporting requirements for a French resident holding shares or maintaining a foreign bank account?
ground_truth: A French resident holding shares outside of France or maintaining a foreign bank account is required to declare all foreign securities, bank, and brokerage accounts, whether open, current, or closed during the tax year, in their annual income tax return.

response:
French residents holding shares or maintaining a foreign bank account are subject to specific reporting requirements under French tax law. Here are the key requirements:

### 1. **Reporting of Foreign Bank Accounts**
- **Declaration Requirement**: French residents must declare all foreign bank accounts, whether open, current, or closed, in their annual income tax return. This includes accounts held in banks outside of France.
- **Deadline**: The declaration must be submitted at the same time as the annual tax return, typically by the end of May or early June, depending on the specific filing deadlines set by the French tax authorities.

### 2. **Reporting of Foreign Securities**
- **Declaration of Foreign Shares**: French residents who hold shares or other securities outside of France are required to declare these holdings in their annual income tax return. This includes both publicly traded and privately held shares.
- **Failure to Comply**: Failure to report foreign bank accounts or securities can lead to significant penalties, including fines and additional taxes owed.

### 3. **Additional Reporting Obligations**
- **Foreign Asset Reporting**: In addition to the annual income tax return, French residents may be required to complete a separate declaration for foreign assets (Form 3916) if they hold foreign bank accounts or securities.
- **Wealth Tax Considerations**: If the total value of foreign assets exceeds specific thresholds, individuals may also be subject to wealth tax (Impôt de Solidarité sur la Fortune, ISF), which requires additional reporting.

### Summary

In summary, French residents holding shares or maintaining a foreign bank account must declare these holdings in their annual income tax return and potentially complete additional forms. Compliance with these reporting requirements is essential to avoid penalties and ensure adherence to French tax regulations.

question: How can the issuance of preferred stock by the board of directors affect the voting power or control of the company?
ground_truth: The board of directors may authorize the issuance of preferred stock with voting or conversion rights that could adversely affect the voting power or other rights of the holders of the common stock.

Our board of directors also can increase or decrease the number of shares of any series, but not below the number of shares of that series then outstanding, without any further vote or action by our stockholders. Anti-Takeover Provisions

So long as the outstanding shares of our Class B common stock represent a majority of the combined voting power of common stock, Mark

Amended and Restated Certificate of Incorporation and Bylaw Provisions

response:
The issuance of preferred stock by the board of directors can significantly affect the voting power and control of a company in several ways:

### 1. **Voting Rights**
- **Limited or No Voting Rights**: Preferred stock typically has limited or no voting rights compared to common stock. This means that when a company issues preferred stock, it may dilute the voting power of common stockholders, especially if a substantial amount of preferred stock is issued.
- **Different Voting Powers**: If the preferred stock does carry voting rights, these rights may differ from those of common stock. For example, preferred stockholders might have the right to vote on specific matters or in certain circumstances, which can influence corporate decisions.

### 2. **Control Dynamics**
- **Control by Preferred Stockholders**: Depending on the terms of the preferred stock, preferred stockholders may gain control over certain decisions if their shares carry special voting rights or if they have the ability to convert their shares into common stock. This could shift control away from common stockholders.
- **Impact on Common Stockholders**: The issuance of preferred stock may lead to a situation where common stockholders have reduced influence over corporate governance, particularly if preferred stockholders are granted significant rights or privileges.

### 3. **Dividend Preferences**
- **Priority in Dividends**: Preferred stockholders typically receive dividends before common stockholders. This preference can affect the financial resources available for common stock dividends and influence the priorities of the board in managing the company’s profits, potentially impacting common stockholder interests.
- **Attracting Investment**: Issuing preferred stock can attract investors looking for fixed dividends and lower risk, but it may also lead to a shift in the company's focus toward fulfilling the obligations to preferred stockholders, sometimes at the expense of common stockholder interests.

### 4. **Anti-Takeover Mechanism**
- **Defensive Strategy**: The issuance of preferred stock can be used as an anti-takeover measure. By creating a class of shares that can be issued to friendly investors or management, a company can make it more difficult for hostile parties to gain control. This can serve to entrench existing management and dilute the influence of potential acquirers.
- **Rights and Provisions**: Preferred stock can come with specific rights and provisions that may further deter takeovers, such as the ability to convert to common stock under certain conditions or to receive additional benefits in the event of a merger.

### 5. **Impact on Future Financing**
- **Influence on Capital Structure**: The issuance of preferred stock changes the company’s capital structure, which can affect future financing decisions. If preferred stock becomes a significant part of the capital structure, it may alter the perception of the company's risk profile and influence the terms of future equity or debt financing.
- **Potential for Dilution**: If preferred stockholders have conversion rights, the eventual conversion to common stock could lead to dilution of existing common stockholders’ voting power, further impacting control dynamics.

### Summary

In summary, the issuance of preferred stock can affect the voting power and control of a company by limiting the voting rights of common stockholders, potentially shifting control dynamics, establishing priorities in dividend distribution, serving as an anti-takeover mechanism, and influencing future financing decisions. As such, the terms of preferred stock issuance are crucial for determining its impact on corporate governance and shareholder control.

### Severance Costs
- **Total Estimated Costs**: Meta estimated total pre-tax severance and related personnel costs of approximately **$1.2 billion** across its Family of Apps (FoA) and Reality Labs (RL) segments.

question: What's the immediate financial effect of Conditional Shares on participants, excluding vacation pay and pension?

response:
The immediate financial effect of Conditional Shares (often referred to as Performance Shares or Restricted Stock Units) on participants can include several key aspects, excluding vacation pay and pension considerations:

### 1. **Value of Conditional Shares**
- **Potential Value**: Conditional Shares represent a promise of future value based on the company's stock performance or other performance metrics. Participants may not realize any immediate cash benefit, but they have the potential to gain value if the conditions for vesting are met and the shares are ultimately granted.
- **Market Price Impact**: The value of Conditional Shares is tied to the market price of the company’s stock at the time they vest. If the stock price increases, the value of the shares becomes more significant, positively impacting the participants' financial outlook.

### 2. **Tax Implications**
- **Taxation Upon Vesting**: Participants may incur tax liabilities when the Conditional Shares vest and are converted into actual shares. The fair market value of the shares at the time of vesting is typically subject to income tax, which can have an immediate financial impact on the participant's net income.
- **Capital Gains Tax**: If participants sell the shares after they vest, any gain realized (the difference between the sale price and the fair market value at vesting) may be subject to capital gains tax, affecting their overall financial position.

### 3. **Impact on Cash Flow**
- **Liquidity Considerations**: While Conditional Shares themselves do not provide immediate cash, participants may need to plan for potential tax payments when the shares vest. This could impact their short-term cash flow if they need to sell some shares to cover tax liabilities.
- **Opportunity Cost**: Participants may experience an opportunity cost if their investment is tied up in Conditional Shares rather than accessible cash or liquid assets. This can affect their ability to invest in other opportunities or cover immediate expenses.

### 4. **Employee Motivation and Retention**
- **Incentive Alignment**: Conditional Shares are designed to align the interests of participants with those of shareholders, potentially motivating employees to work toward improving company performance. This can indirectly affect their financial situation by enhancing job security and growth opportunities within the company.
- **Retention Effects**: The vesting schedule associated with Conditional Shares often serves to retain employees over a specified period. Participants may feel more secure in their positions, which can have a positive impact on their overall financial planning and stability.

### Summary

In summary, the immediate financial effects of Conditional Shares on participants primarily revolve around the potential value derived from the shares, tax implications upon vesting, cash flow considerations related to tax liabilities, and the motivational aspects that can influence job security and retention. While Conditional Shares do not provide immediate cash benefits, their eventual realization can significantly impact participants' financial situations.

question: How do COSO criteria secure Meta's financial reports and assets?
ground_truth: The COSO criteria secure Meta's financial reports and assets by providing a framework for internal control over financial reporting. This includes maintaining records that accurately reflect transactions and dispositions of assets, ensuring transactions are recorded to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and providing assurance regarding the prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company's assets.

federal tax liability, plus interest and any penalties asserted. The Company uses judgment to (1) determine whether a tax position's technical merits are more-likely-than-not to be sustained and (2) measure the amount of tax benefit that qualifies for recognition.

Auditing the Company's accounting for, and disclosure of, these uncertain tax positions was especially challenging due to the significant judgment required to assess management's evaluation of technical merits and the measurement of the tax position based on interpretations of tax laws and legal rulings.

How We Addressed the Matter in Our Audit

We obtained an understanding, evaluated the design and tested the operating effectiveness of controls over the Company's process to assess the technical merits of tax positions related to these transfer pricing agreements and to measure the benefit of those tax positions.

As part of our audit procedures over the Company's accounting for these positions, we involved our tax professionals to assist with our assessment of the technical merits of the Company's tax positions. This included assessing the Company's correspondence with the relevant tax authorities, evaluating income tax opinions or other third-party advice obtained by the Company, and requesting and receiving confirmation letters from third-party advisors. We also used our knowledge of, and experience with, the application of international and local income tax laws by the relevant income tax authorities to evaluate the Company's accounting for those tax positions. We analyzed the Company's assumptions and data used to determine the amount of the federal tax liability recognized and tested the mathematical accuracy of the underlying data and calculations. We also evaluated the appropriateness of the related disclosures included in Note 16 to the consolidated financial statements in relation to these matters.

/s/ Ernst & Young LLP

We have served as the Company's auditor since 2007.

San Mateo, California February 1, 2023

83

Table of Contents

Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm

To the Stockholders and the Board of Directors of Meta Platforms, Inc.

Opinion on Internal Control over Financial Reporting

We have audited Meta Platforms, Inc.'s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2022, based on criteria established in Internal Control – Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (2013 framework), (the COSO criteria). In our opinion, Meta Platforms, Inc. (the Company) maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2022, based on the COSO criteria.

We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States) (PCAOB), the consolidated balance sheets of the Company as of December 31, 2022 and 2021, the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, stockholders' equity and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2022, and the related notes and our report dated February 1, 2023 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.

Basis for Opinion

The Company's management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting included in the accompanying Management's Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company's internal control over financial reporting based on our audit. We are a public accounting firm registered with the PCAOB and are required to be independent with respect to the Company in accordance with the U.S. federal securities laws and the applicable rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the PCAOB.

We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the PCAOB. Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.

Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances. We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.

Definition and Limitations of Internal Control Over Financial Reporting

A company's internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. A company's internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company's assets
response:
The COSO (Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission) criteria provide a comprehensive framework for internal control that helps organizations, including Meta, secure their financial reports and assets. Here’s how the COSO criteria contribute to the integrity of financial reporting and asset protection:

### 1. **Control Environment**
- **Foundation of Internal Control**: The control environment sets the tone for the organization and establishes a culture of accountability and integrity. Meta’s commitment to ethical behavior, governance, and compliance helps ensure that financial reporting processes are reliable.
- **Management’s Role**: Strong leadership and clear responsibilities within Meta foster an environment where employees understand the importance of internal controls and their role in safeguarding assets and ensuring accurate reporting.

### 2. **Risk Assessment**
- **Identifying Risks**: COSO emphasizes the importance of identifying and assessing risks that could affect financial reporting and asset protection. Meta conducts regular risk assessments to understand potential threats, such as fraud, data breaches, or operational inefficiencies.
- **Mitigation Strategies**: By recognizing these risks, Meta can implement appropriate controls and responses, reducing the likelihood of material misstatements in financial reports and protecting its assets.

### 3. **Control Activities**
- **Implementation of Controls**: COSO encourages the establishment of control activities, such as approvals, authorizations, verifications, and reconciliations. Meta applies these activities to ensure that transactions are processed accurately and that assets are safeguarded.
- **Segregation of Duties**: By separating responsibilities among different individuals, Meta minimizes the risk of errors or fraud. For example, the person responsible for recording transactions is not the same as the person responsible for authorizing them.

### 4. **Information and Communication**
- **Timely and Relevant Information**: Effective communication channels ensure that relevant information regarding financial reporting and asset management flows throughout the organization. Meta promotes transparency and facilitates the sharing of information necessary for decision-making.
- **Training and Awareness**: Educating employees about internal control processes and their importance enhances compliance and helps in the prevention of errors or fraud.

### 5. **Monitoring Activities**
- **Ongoing Monitoring**: COSO stresses the importance of continuous monitoring of the internal control system. Meta regularly evaluates the effectiveness of its controls through audits and assessments to identify areas for improvement.
- **Feedback Mechanisms**: Establishing feedback loops allows Meta to address any deficiencies in the internal control system promptly, ensuring that financial reports remain accurate and assets are protected.

### 6. **Compliance with Regulations**
- **Adherence to Standards**: By implementing COSO criteria, Meta ensures compliance with applicable laws and regulations, such as the Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX). This compliance is crucial for maintaining investor confidence and protecting the company’s reputation.
- **Audit Preparedness**: A robust internal control framework facilitates external audits, providing assurance to stakeholders that financial reports are reliable and that assets are managed appropriately.

### Summary

In summary, the COSO criteria secure Meta's financial reports and assets by establishing a strong control environment, conducting thorough risk assessments, implementing effective control activities, ensuring clear communication, monitoring internal controls, and complying with regulatory requirements. This comprehensive approach helps mitigate risks, enhances the reliability of financial reporting, and protects the organization’s assets.

These amendments were adopted in accordance with Section 242 of the General Corporation Law of the State of Delaware.

Any director elected in accordance with the preceding sentence shall hold office for a term expiring at the annual meeting of stockholders at which the term of office of the class to which the director has been elected expires or until such director’s successor shall have been duly elected and qualified.

6. Vote by Ballot. Election of directors need not be by written ballot.

ARTICLE VII: DIRECTOR LIABILITY; INDEMNIFICATION

1. Limitation of Liability. To the fullest extent permitted by law, no director of the corporation shall be personally liable to the corporation or its stockholders for monetary damages for breach of fiduciary duty as a director. Without limiting the effect of the preceding sentence, if the General Corporation Law is hereafter amended to authorize the further elimination or limitation of the liability of a director, then the liability of a director of the corporation shall be eliminated or limited to the fullest extent permitted by the General Corporation Law, as so amended.

2. Indemnification. The corporation shall indemnify to the fullest extent permitted by law any person made or threatened to be made a party to an action or proceeding, whether criminal, civil, administrative or investigative, by reason of the fact that he, his testator or intestate is or was a director or officer of the corporation or any predecessor of the Corporation, or serves or served at any other enterprise as a director or officer at the request of the corporation or any predecessor to the corporation. 11

3. Change in Rights. Neither any amendment nor repeal of this ARTICLE VII, nor the adoption of any provision of this Restated Certificate of Incorporation inconsistent with this ARTICLE VII, shall eliminate or reduce the effect of this Article VII in respect of any matter occurring, or any action or proceeding accruing or arising or that, but for this Article VII, would accrue or arise, prior to such amendment, repeal or adoption of an inconsistent provision. ARTICLE VIII: MATTERS RELATING TO STOCKHOLDERS

1. No Action by Written Consent of Stockholders. Subject to the rights of the holders of any series of Preferred Stock with respect to actions by the holders of shares of such series, from and after the Voting Threshold Date, (a) no action shall be taken by the stockholders of the corporation except at a duly called annual or special meeting of stockholders and (b) no action shall be taken by the stockholders of the corporation by written consent.

2. Special Meeting of Stockholders. Subject to the rights of the holders of any series of Preferred Stock with respect to actions by the holders of shares of such series, special meetings of the stockholders of the corporation may be called only by the Board of Directors acting pursuant to a resolution adopted by a majority of the Whole Board, the Chief Executive Officer, President or the Chairperson of the Board, and may not be called by any other person or persons. Business transacted at special meetings of stockholders shall be confined to the purpose or purposes stated in the notice of meeting.

3. Advance Notice of Stockholder Nominations. Advance notice of stockholder nominations for the election of directors of the corporation and of business to be brought by stockholders before any meeting of stockholders of the corporation shall be given in the manner provided in the Bylaws of the corporation.

4. Business Combinations. The corporation elects not to be governed by Section 203 of the General Corporation Law.

ARTICLE IX: CHOICE OF FORUM

Unless the corporation consents in writing to the selection of an alternative forum, the Court of Chancery of the State of Delaware shall, to the fullest extent permitted by law,

be the sole and exclusive forum for (1) any derivative action or proceeding brought on behalf of the corporation, (2) any action asserting a claim of breach of a fiduciary duty owed by, or other wrongdoing by, any director, officer, employee or agent of the corporation to the corporation or the corporation’s stockholders, (3) any action asserting a claim arising pursuant to any provision of the General Corporation Law or the corporation’s Restated Certificate of Incorporation or Bylaws, (4) any action to interpret, apply, enforce or determine the validity of the corporation’s Restated Certificate of Incorporation or Bylaws or (5) any action asserting a claim governed by the internal affairs doctrine, in each such case subject to said Court of Chancery having personal jurisdiction over the indispensable parties named as defendants therein. Any person or entity purchasing or otherwise acquiring any interest in shares of capital stock of the corporation shall be deemed to have notice of and consented to the provisions of this ARTICLE IX.

ARTICLE X: AMENDMENT OF RESTATED CERTIFICATE OF INCORPORATION

Delaware law significantly influences how companies like Meta handle incorporation amendments and director liability. Here’s an overview of how recent changes in Delaware law may affect Meta in these areas:

### 1. **Incorporation Amendments**
- **Flexibility in Corporate Governance**: Delaware law allows companies to amend their certificates of incorporation and bylaws relatively easily. Meta can make changes to its governance structure, capital structure, or other provisions without significant hurdles, as long as these amendments are approved by the board of directors and, in some cases, the stockholders.

Meta may need to consider these rights when amending its incorporation documents to ensure compliance and maintain shareholder confidence.

### 2. **Director Liability**
- **Limitation of Liability**: Delaware law provides that a corporation's certificate of incorporation may include provisions that limit or eliminate the personal liability of directors for breaches of fiduciary duty. This means that Meta can amend its certificate to protect its directors from personal liability for monetary damages, except in specific cases, such as breaches of loyalty or acts not in good faith.
- **Recent Legal Precedents**: Recent court decisions in Delaware have clarified and sometimes expanded the scope of protections available to directors, which may encourage Meta to adopt more robust indemnification provisions in its governance documents. This can enhance the attractiveness of board positions and help recruit qualified directors.

### 3. **Indemnification Provisions**
- **Broader Indemnification**: Delaware law allows companies to indemnify directors and officers to a great extent. Meta can amend its bylaws to provide comprehensive indemnification against expenses, liabilities, and losses incurred in connection with their roles, further protecting its leadership from potential legal repercussions.
- **Insurance Considerations**: Amendments related to indemnification may also affect Meta’s liability insurance policies. The company must consider how these provisions align with its insurance coverage and the potential financial implications of claims made against directors or officers.

### 4. **Impact of Recent Legislative Changes**
- **Corporate Transparency and Accountability**: Recent amendments to Delaware corporate law have increased transparency and accountability, requiring companies to disclose more information about their governance practices. Meta may need to amend its incorporation documents to comply with these new requirements, ensuring that it is transparent about director compensation, board diversity, and other governance matters.
- **Evolving Standards**: As Delaware continues to evolve its corporate governance standards, Meta must stay abreast of these changes to ensure compliance and to leverage any opportunities that may arise from favorable legal interpretations or legislative updates.

### Summary

In summary, Delaware law affects Meta's incorporation amendments and director liability by providing flexibility in governance, allowing for limitations on director liability, and enabling comprehensive indemnification provisions. Recent changes in Delaware law emphasize shareholder rights and corporate accountability, which may prompt Meta to amend its governance documents to align with these evolving standards. By doing so, Meta can enhance the protection of its directors and officers while ensuring compliance with Delaware’s legal framework.

question: What ensures reliable financial reporting in SOX 302?
ground_truth: Reliable financial reporting in SOX 302 is ensured by designing internal control over financial reporting, or causing such internal control over financial reporting to be designed under supervision, to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
response:
Section 302 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 (SOX) establishes key requirements that ensure reliable financial reporting by publicly traded companies. Here are the main components that contribute to the reliability of financial reports under SOX 302:

### 1. **Certification of Financial Reports**
- **Management Certification**: SOX 302 requires the principal executive officer and the principal financial officer to certify the accuracy and completeness of the financial reports. This personal accountability ensures that top management is directly responsible for the integrity of financial statements.

### 2. **Establishment of Internal Controls**
- **Internal Control Framework**: Companies must maintain effective internal controls over financial reporting (ICFR). This includes processes and procedures designed to ensure the reliability of financial reporting and compliance with applicable laws and regulations.
- **Regular Evaluation**: Management is required to evaluate the effectiveness of these internal controls regularly. This ongoing assessment helps identify weaknesses or deficiencies that could lead to misstatements in financial reporting.

### 3. **Disclosure of Material Changes**
- **Prompt Disclosure**: SOX 302 mandates that management disclose any material changes in the company’s internal control over financial reporting or any significant deficiencies in these controls. This transparency helps stakeholders understand the reliability of the financial information being presented.

### 4. **Prohibition of Misleading Information**
- **Accuracy of Reports**: The law prohibits the submission of misleading financial reports. Management must ensure that all financial statements fairly present the company’s financial condition, results of operations, and cash flows in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP).

### 5. **Training and Awareness**
- **Employee Training**: Companies are encouraged to provide training and resources to employees involved in financial reporting and internal controls. This ensures that all personnel understand the importance of accurate financial reporting and their role in maintaining effective controls.

### 6. **Audit Committee Oversight**
- **Involvement of Audit Committees**: SOX emphasizes the role of the audit committee, which is responsible for overseeing the financial reporting process and the effectiveness of internal controls. This independent oversight adds another layer of reliability to the financial reporting process.

### 7. **External Auditors**
- **Collaboration with External Auditors**: Companies must work closely with external auditors who review and attest to the effectiveness of internal controls over financial reporting. This independent verification helps ensure the accuracy of financial statements.

### Summary

In summary, SOX 302 ensures reliable financial reporting through management certification of financial reports, the establishment and evaluation of internal controls, prompt disclosure of material changes, the prohibition of misleading information, employee training, audit committee oversight, and collaboration with external auditors. Together, these components create a framework that promotes transparency, accountability, and the integrity of financial reporting for publicly traded companies.

question: How do lower user engagement and ad pricing changes affect social media market share?
ground_truth: Lower user engagement and ad pricing changes can lead to a loss of advertising market share to competitors, especially if competitors offer lower priced, more integrated, or otherwise more effective products.
response:
Lower user engagement and changes in ad pricing can significantly impact the market share of social media companies. Here’s how these factors interact and influence competitive dynamics within the industry:

### 1. **Impact of Lower User Engagement**
- **Reduced Advertising Effectiveness**: Lower user engagement often leads to fewer interactions with ads, which can diminish the overall effectiveness of advertising campaigns. Advertisers may find that their return on investment (ROI) decreases, leading them to reconsider their spending on platforms with declining engagement.
- **Attraction of Competitors**: As user engagement drops on a particular platform, users may migrate to competitors that offer more engaging content or experiences. For instance, platforms like TikTok have gained popularity by providing more engaging and interactive content, which can lure users away from traditional platforms like Facebook and Instagram.
- **Decreased Ad Revenue**: With lower engagement levels, social media companies may experience a decline in ad impressions and clicks, directly affecting their revenue. This can lead to reduced budgets for marketing and innovation, further impacting user experience and engagement.

### 2. **Changes in Ad Pricing**
- **Increased Competition for Ad Spend**: If a social media platform raises its ad prices without corresponding increases in user engagement or effectiveness, advertisers may shift their budgets to more cost-effective platforms. This can lead to a loss of market share for the platform that raised prices.
- **Ad Pricing Strategies**: Conversely, if a platform lowers its ad prices to attract advertisers during periods of low engagement, it may temporarily boost revenue but could also devalue its ad inventory. Advertisers may question the quality and effectiveness of lower-priced ads, which could impact long-term relationships and brand perception.
- **Market Positioning**: Companies that successfully manage ad pricing strategies in response to user engagement trends can enhance their competitive positioning. For example, offering competitive pricing while maintaining user engagement can attract more advertisers and increase market share.

### 3. **Long-Term Effects on Market Share**
- **Brand Loyalty and Perception**: Continuous low engagement can harm a brand’s reputation, making it difficult to retain existing users and attract new ones. If users perceive a platform as less engaging or valuable, they are more likely to switch to competitors, further eroding market share.
- **Innovation and Content Quality**: To combat declines in engagement and adapt to pricing changes, social media platforms may need to innovate and improve content quality. Failure to do so can result in a stagnant user base and declining market share, as users seek out platforms that offer better experiences.
- **Strategic Partnerships and Investments**: Platforms may seek partnerships or invest in new technologies to enhance user engagement and improve ad effectiveness. This can help regain lost market share by creating a more compelling offering for both users and advertisers.

### Summary

In summary, lower user engagement can negatively affect a social media platform's attractiveness to advertisers, leading to decreased ad revenue and potential market share loss. Changes in ad pricing can either mitigate or exacerbate these effects, depending on how they are implemented and perceived by advertisers. Platforms that adapt to these challenges through strategic pricing, innovation, and improved user experiences are more likely to maintain or grow their market share in a competitive landscape.

These are fundamentally new technologies that we expect will evolve as the metaverse ecosystem develops, and many products for the metaverse may only be fully realized in the next decade. response:
Meta Spark plays a crucial role in advancing Meta's augmented reality (AR) efforts and aligning with its broader metaverse goals. Here’s how it contributes to these objectives:

### 1. **Platform for AR Creation**
- **Empowering Creators**: Meta Spark provides tools and resources for creators and developers to build augmented reality experiences. By enabling users to create their own AR content, Meta fosters a vibrant ecosystem that encourages innovation and creativity, which is essential for the growth of AR within the metaverse.
- **User-Generated Content**: The platform supports user-generated content, allowing individuals and businesses to create engaging AR experiences that can be shared across Meta’s applications (like Instagram and Facebook). This increases user engagement and enhances the overall AR landscape.

### 2. **Integration with Meta's Ecosystem**
- **Cross-Platform Functionality**: Meta Spark integrates seamlessly with Meta's existing platforms, enabling AR experiences to be easily accessed and utilized across social media channels. This integration helps Meta leverage its vast user base to drive adoption and engagement with AR content.
- **Enhancing User Experience**: By incorporating AR features into its apps, Meta Spark enhances the user experience, making interactions more immersive and engaging. This aligns with Meta’s goal of creating a more interconnected and interactive metaverse.

### 3. **Support for Business Applications**
- **Tools for Brands and Businesses**: Meta Spark offers businesses the ability to create AR advertising and marketing campaigns. This not only enhances brand visibility but also allows companies to engage customers in innovative ways, driving revenue and interest in AR technology.
- **Analytics and Insights**: Businesses using Meta Spark can access analytics to understand how users interact with their AR content, helping them refine their strategies and improve engagement. This data-driven approach supports Meta’s goal of creating effective and compelling experiences in the metaverse.

### 4. **Long-Term Vision for the Metaverse**
- **Foundation for Future AR Innovations**: Meta Spark is part of Meta’s long-term strategy to build the metaverse, serving as a foundational platform for future AR innovations. By investing in AR technology and encouraging its development, Meta aims to create a richer, more immersive virtual environment that combines the digital and physical worlds.
- **Research and Development**: The insights gained from Meta Spark and its applications contribute to Meta’s research and development efforts in AR. This ongoing innovation is vital for overcoming technological challenges and advancing the capabilities of AR within the metaverse.

### 5. **Community and Collaboration**
- **Building a Developer Community**: By providing tools and resources through Meta Spark, Meta fosters a community of developers and creators who can collaborate and share ideas. This community-driven approach is essential for driving innovation and expanding the range of AR experiences available in the metaverse.
- **Partnership Opportunities**: Meta Spark opens up opportunities for partnerships with other tech companies, developers, and brands, further enhancing the AR ecosystem. Collaborations can lead to new applications and experiences that enrich the metaverse.

### Summary

In summary, Meta Spark significantly aids Meta's AR efforts by providing a platform for creators, integrating with Meta's ecosystem, supporting business applications, and contributing to the long-term vision of the metaverse. By fostering innovation, enhancing user experiences, and building a collaborative community, Meta Spark aligns with Meta's goals of creating a more immersive and interconnected digital environment.

question: How could regs and liabilities affect financials and stock value in acquisitions?
ground_truth: Regulatory challenges and liabilities can significantly affect financials and stock value in acquisitions. Regulatory challenges may prevent the completion of acquisitions or require divestitures, as seen with the United Kingdom Competition and Markets Authority directing the divestment of the Giphy acquisition. Liabilities or deficiencies discovered post-acquisition can lead to unanticipated costs. These factors can adversely affect financial condition, results of operations, and the price of common stock.
contexts:

As part of our business strategy, we have made and intend to continue to make acquisitions to add specialized employees and complementary companies, products, or technologies, and from time to time may enter into other strategic transactions such as investments and joint ventures. We may not be able to find suitable acquisition candidates, and we may not be able to complete acquisitions or other strategic transactions on favorable terms, or at all, including as a result of regulatory challenges. For example, in 2022, the United Kingdom Competition and Markets Authority directed us to divest our Giphy acquisition. In addition, although we were subsequently able to complete the acquisition in 2023, in 2022, the FTC filed lawsuits against us to enjoin our proposed acquisition of Within Unlimited. In some cases, the costs of such acquisitions or other strategic transactions may be substantial, and there is no assurance that we will realize expected synergies and potential monetization opportunities for our acquisitions or a favorable return on investment for our strategic investments.

We may pay substantial amounts of cash or incur debt to pay for acquisitions or other strategic transactions, which has occurred in the past and could adversely affect our liquidity.
